VOL. XXV. No. 22

OTEMS
BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 22, 1921

DRAMATIC CLUB MAY TAKE
"ARMS AND THE MAN"

FIRST JAZZ ,DEBATE A
DISTINCT SUCCESS.

Will Serve As Excellent Advertisement of University—New Men
Taken Into Club.

Seniors Fall Before Onslaught of Junior Speakers—"Mike" Bowers'
Orchestra Delights Dancers.
Large Attendance Attracted by Innovation

The Dramatic Club is now
deeply concerned with plans to
take "Arms and the Man" on the
road. It is hoped that later in
the spring it will be able to perform in some of the smaller Western Maryland towns. This will
offer an opportunity of introducing a Hopkins organization to
the people of that district and will
advertise the college besides enabling the club to get funds to
pay off some of the loans made by
members last year.
At the last meeting in the
studio the members of the cast
made eligible for membership in
the club by participation in "Arms
and the Man" were formally
taken in.
Although the performance of
"Arms and the Man" is over, every
one who saw it or took part in
it is still talking about it with
much praise. What speaks well
for the Dramatic Club is that little of the comment is obverse and
that critics in all places have commented most favorably on the production. Henry West, as Louka,
seems in most minds to have been
the best of the cast, the most
natural in his part and the best
costumed of the three female roles.
Joe Moran's voice was far less
like that of a heroine only because
of a very bad cold which he contracted several days before the
performance. Pierce Brawner is
still speaking of the jar he had
When in the second act he asked
Major Petkoff where Riana was,
only to have the girl herself
answer from behind "Riana is
here" in tones of very masculine
pitch, whereas Brawner had expected, a delicate soft response.
Mossom is coming in for his share
of praise along with Basford and
Trew for his excellent acting and
is being constantly reminded of
his idiosyncrasies in the part of
Major Petkoff which brought so
many laughs.
CROSS COUNTRY TEAM
At a meeting of the Athletic Association held March
17 it was recommended that
the Cross Country Team be
made an organization separate from the track team, and
that it elect its own special
captain. An "H" is to be
awarded any man placing in
the Southern Intercollegiate
Championships and a "cHc"
to a point winner in any other
meet. This recommendation
must be voted upon by the
student-body before it can
be adopted.

The Junior-Senior debate and
dance held last Saturday evening
was a distinct success. The debate—which the Juniors won by
unanimous decision — was well
contested, and the speakers held
the interest of the audience at all
times. The subject was: "Resolved, That the United States
should adopt a policy of further
material restriction of immigration." Morris Keen, first speaker
for the affirmative, argued that
the recent type of immigrant is
vastly inferior and less assimilable than the older type, and that
very few take the trouble to learn
our language. He claimed that
Europe needs its man-power now
if never before. Burdelle S. Cannon, first speaker for '21, said that
the present law, if properly enforced, is restrictive and strict
enough to efficiently exclude all
undesirables..
C. C. Marbury devoted his
speech to the dangers of Japanese
immigration, and showed that in
consideration of the very high
birth rate among the Japanese,
California will have come under
the control of the Japs by 1949,
unless some means is found to
stop the flood of Orientals. He
claimed that Japan is not living
up to the "Gentlemen's Agreement," and is sending laborers to
America in direct violation of this
agreement. He favored an immigration plan which would exclude
the Japanese and would limit
European immigrants• to 5 per
cent. of those already here; each
separate country to send immigrants in a definite proportion to
those who become nationalized in
this country. Harold Reed, for
the negative, denied that there are
any inherent objectionable faults
in the modern immigrant, and protested the statement that criminals
are usually aliens. He said that
we need the immigrant to do the
sort of "dirty work" that Americans refuse to do. Louis Macht
in the negative rebuttal drew a
laugh when he said:."My opponents have pointed out Owen Johnson as an authority favoring restriction of immtgration. Now,
Dr. Dunlap, sitting right here in
front of me, says that Owen Johnson appeals only to the lowest type
of intellect." Macht attempted to
refute. the- statement that there
will be more immigration in the
future than in the past. R. Dorsey
(Continued on page 8 col. 2)

PRICE 10 CENTS

BALL TEAM PREPARING FOR PETITION FOR LIMITATION
OF ENROLLMENT ENGAME WITH VIRGINIA
DORSED BY LEADING
MEN ON CAMPUS
Infield Positions Practically Filled.
Seven Men Showing Up Evenly
In Outfield—First Game At
Charlottesville On
March 26.

The Johns Hopkins basketball
team is rapidly rounding into excellent form for their first encounter with the University of Virginia
at Charlottesville, Va., on March
26. Coach Herb Armstrong has
a squad of 40 men working out
daily at Homewood and has been
having a difficult time picking out
the best combination but by elimidefinitely denation has almost'
cided upon the line-up for the
opening game.
Catchers who have been showing up well are "Bill" Wood, last
year's mainstay, and Levin. It is
quite likely that Wood will continue to receive the delivery of
Tucker, Shipley and Owings, Marchetti, Ellicott and Macht. Tucker
is a former St. John's man with
a good reputation and a strong
arm. Owings is through with basketball now and will endeavor to
get in form as rapidly as possible without injury to his arm.
Andy Knecht looks good at first
and with Grace at second, Reifschneider at short and Captain
Sharretts at third Hopkins has a
well balanced infield. Outfielders
are Mader, Merrick, Wells, Rich,
Chandler, Miller and Thomas; the
first three named bat left-handed
and all are sluggers. Thomas was
captain of last year's team at City
College and looks like the logical
man for one of the field positions.
Substitute infielders are Strouse
and Middleton, so that with this
formidable array of stars and exstars Hopkins' outlook for the
present season is quite favorable.
Freshmen practice was inaugurated Thursday, but only a few
men showed up. A schedule of
games has been arranged by Manager Vanneman, which includes
three trips away from home and
home games have been arranged
with some of the best prep teams
in this vicinity and with college
freshmen teams. Turnbull will
coach the Freshmen and with more
men out surely can develop a winning aggregation. Barton has
been catching for the first-year
men, with Chalmers on the mound
and McBurney at shortstop.
Mount, Pinder and Donnatell
have been holding down the outfield positions.
SENIORS

Pay your class, dues to T. F.
Hubbard. You can find him on
the third floor of the C. E. Building at any time. He can't chase
after you. Anyone who has not
paid by April 5 will have his
picture left out of the Hullabaloo:

Members of Faculty Also hi Favor of
Plan To Go Before Committee
On Admission And Advanced
Standing Shortly.

Following the suggestion of
last week's NEWS-LETTER editorial
in reference to a limitation of
future freshmen enrollment, the
following petition has been drawn
up and been endorsed by several
members of the faculty, including
Drs. Ames, Roulston and French,
and by the leaders of practically
every athletic and nonathletic organization on the campus. Thehonorary fraternity, Omicron
Delta Kappa, is also heartily in
favor of the move, which will
place the limited facilities of the
university in the hands of those
most deserving them. The petition
will be placed for ratification before the Committee on Admissions
and Advanced Standing at the
next meeting of that body.
The petition follows:
Whereas, the university is unable because of inadequate facilities to provide suitable education
for a larger number of students
than are now enrolled.
Whereas, the great increase in
the number of students without
the proper facilities for taking
care of them has impaired the
standing, college
educational
spirit and environment of other
colleges and universities.
Whereas, we fear that there is
danger of a similar condition of
affairs at our own university, we
submit the following petition:
That the size of the class of
1925 and succeeding classes be
limited to a fixed number.
That the admission of students
to the university in the future be
based not solely upon scholarship
but upon character and personality as well.
And that in all cases where possible a personal interview with the
dean or.Committee on Admissions
and Advanced Standing be required.

TRACK MEN
K. R. Mulliken, captain of
the Johns. Hopkins Track
Team, is desirous that all
former track men and any
.candidates who. wish to try
for places on the team report
to the Homewood field daily
at 3.45 P. M. for practice.
An attractive schedule of
meets has been arranged for
the outdoor season, which
promises to be every bit as
successful as was the indoor
season.

MODEST ACTOR DIAGNOSES HOPKINS' ILLS.

Last Thursday, in the neighborhood of 2 o'clock, the university
was honored by an unofficial visit
from Guy Robertson, leading man
with "Mary," the musical comedy
playing in town last week.
Modestly clad in a dove-colored
soft hat, cream-colored overcoat,
checker-board vest and a flowing
green tie, the blue-eyed dispenser
of love and music "jazzed" into the
Student Activities Building and
proceeded to make himself at
home.
After "kidding" everyone in the
athletic office, he sobered down
long enough to tell about himself.
After spending three years at
Lehigh, studying "at" civil engineering, playing quarterback on
the football team, having his nose
broken in the annual Lafayette
clash and finally "flunking," he
left by "mutual consent," returned
home to little old New York and
entered vaudeville. From then he
rose, till at his present age of 21,
he ascended to the heights of musical comedy in "Mary.
He diagnosed Hopkins' troubles
in few words. Too many students;
too few athletes, too much blacklist and too few co-eds is the
trouble mostly. And he finished
by saying we'd never beat Lehigh
in lacrosse again.
After which he offered to treat
everyone present, bought a fountain ipen from Dr. Adams,
pocketed the $495 change (of his
week's salary) and went "jazzing"
back to Ford's to sing "Love
Nest" softly to Virginia O'Brien.

PIPES

MUSICAL CLUB GIVES
CONCERT
Hopkins Musicians Delight Audience
At Harlem Square Church.
Speaker Loses Suspender Button.

The concert given by the combined musical clubs at the Harlem
Square Church last Wednesday
night, March 16, which was in
reality more or less of a dress
rehearsal, was very successful.
The program was opened by the
singing of the Univ_ersity Ode by
the Glee Club. The Orchestra
rallied nobly to an Intermezzo
from Iris, "Mike" Bowers directing with a black fountain pen.
Coulter, accompanied by the Glee
Club, next sang "On the Road to
Maudalay," which was received in
grand style. The audience now
being thoroughly asleep was suddenly aroused by the Orchestra
playing a martial air in staccato
time. The Quartet retaliated with
"The Cornfield Melody," composed
by Mr. Speaker, director of the
club. Following up with an encore, Mr. Speaker and Coulter
sang "Johnnie Schmoker," during
which Mr. Speaker, in leaning
over, lost his suspender button,
much to the merriment of the
audience. The Hawaiian Trio was
excellent, performing in old-time
Hambleton played the
style.
"Rosary" on the steel guitar and
Coulter rendered the "Melody in
F" on the ukelele. The concert
was brought to a successful close
by the playing of "Look for the
Silver Lining," medley from
"Sally," by the Mandolin Club,
and "De Coppah Moon" by the
Glee Club.

The Lost and Found Bureau,
which was established but a few
months ago, has thus far returned
over 750 articles. Quite a variety
of articles have reached their owners through this agency, watches,
fountain pens, furs, jewelry, keys,

C. I. T. Gould, representing
Johns Hopkins, won second place
in the Intercollegiate Southern
Oratorical League Contest held at
Chapel Hill, N. C., last week.
Gould's subject was "America and
the Japanese." David Reid Hodgin, of North Carolina, whose subject was "War Declared," won
first place, while Patrick Henry
Vincent, University of Kentucky,
who spoke on the "Anglo-Irish
Controversy," was third. C. D.
Pepper, of Alabama, presented the
"Immigration Problem"; George
R. Jacob, of Virginia, spoke on the
"Truth About• America," and
Walter T. Whitewell, of Vanderbilt University, had as a subject
"Wanted—A School of Diplomacy." Georgia University and
the University of Tennessee were
entered in the contest but failed
to send representatives.
In attacking his subject Gould
did not favor exclusion of the
Japanese on grounds of inferiority
but for the cause of world peace
and because of racial difference
and the economic well-being of the
American people. He advocated
the abolition of the existing "gentlemen's agreement" and urged a
policy of exclusion in its place.
The presiding officer of the contest was Mr. W.H. Close, of North
Carolina, and the judges were W.
F. Boatwright, president of University of Richmond; Prof. C. R.
Brown, of Roanoke College, and
Prof. Yates Snowden, of the University of South Carolina.
After the contest there was a
banquet at which the constitution
of the league was amended and
it was decided that hereafter instead of the money prizes of $30,
$20 and $10 to winners of first,
second and third places, cups of
medals of corresponding value
would be offered. The contest for
next year was awarded to the
University of Alabama. Officers
of the league were elected as follows: President, C. I. T. Gould,
Johns Hopkins; chairman, Professor McKee, University of North
Carolina; secretary, Mr. McCall,
of Alabama.

UNIT SUFFERING FROM
ABSENTEES
Number of Delinquents Only Cause For
Concern After Two Official Inspections of R. 0. T. C. Last
Week—Many Opportunities In Regular Army
For Seniors.

The one thing that is holding
back the Johns Hopkins Unit of
the R. 0. T. C. in its attempts to
become proficient enough to receive the first place on the "distinguished" list this spring is the
number of inexcused absences
from • drill and classes that are
not made up. This, according to
Major Gary, is the one pronounced
weakness of the unit at present.
The two important inspections of
the military department that occurred last week emphasized the
many blanks on the attendance
charts hanging in the military
office. The first of these inspections was by the office of the
chief of infantry, which has jurisdiction. over Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia. In general
both sets of inspectors appeared
to be very much impressed with
the work being done at Hopkins,
and one officer, after making his
examination and seeing how the
various theoretical classes were
conducted, stated that he thought
that the work being done here was
of as high order as that of any
unit in the country, and further
that he thought that Hopkins
should be made the model unit for
the United States. If the unexcused absences, ranging all
through the year, are made up
and students continue to show
their present interest in the work
and keep up its high quality,
Major Gary believes the rating of
the institution will be very high.
Certainly with a few exceptions
the members of the unit, both officers and students, are bending
every effort to secure the highest
possible rating at the "distinguished" inspection in the spring.
The War Department is giving
to seniors in selected institutions
(among which is Hopkins) exceptional opportunities to enter
the regular army as commissioned
officers, and particularly does this
apply to engineering students.
There are at present vacancies in
the Ordnance Department, in the
Signal Corps and in the Corps of
Engineers. Major Gary believes
that students entering the army
on graduation this spring will be
first lieutenants within a few
months. As such they would receive as pay and allowances a
salary of about $3,000 a year.
Exemptions from examinations
before appointment to a commission will be given to those who
have a certain class standing at
the university. It is Major
Gary's opinion that this condition, where commissions may be
so easily secured and to such good
advantage, will not exist again for
years. Those who are interested
in entering the army should apply
to the military office for further
information.

ELECTIONS.

these facts has been given in the
past, or can be given under the
present system of elections, to
• such questions. Student and class
representatives are elected at hurried, ill-managed meetings, upon
offhand nominations and with little or no discussion or deliberation. Such a system of elections
is obviously unsatisfactory and
should be remedied.
The following method, with
some alteration, has worked out
successfully at other institutions:
All nominations are written and
signed by at least ten men and
are handed to the president of the
student council two weeks before
The
the election takes place.
names and records of the candidates are printed in the student
paper of the week preceding the
,final ballot. Ballots are printed
and on the day of election polls
are erected and kept open under
the supervision of the student
council in such places and for the
length of time that it deems advisable.
Although such a system of elections is more complicated than the
one now in use, it has obvious advantages and, having been used
successfully in many other colleges is certainly worthy of the
consideration of our student council.

STUDENT

Spring, the time - for baseball,
love, cutting classes and elections,
is again with us if the weather,
the robins and our internal feelings are true indications. "Shad"
and Armstrong will take care of
baseball, Baltimore will supply
the girl and the dean will attend
to those delinquents who find the
study of nature more interesting
than the prescribed courses. Elections apparently take care of
themselves.
We have long thought that the
system of class and other student
elections used at Hopkins in the
past is far from satisfactory. The
election of class and student officials should be a matter of careful and weighty consideration. The
men elected represent the students
by whom they are elected, and
upon them will depend largely the
initiative and spirit of those they
represent.
Far too little consideration of

For a good many years Hopkins
students have been criticised for
their lack of college spirit. The
reply to this criticism' has always
been that there was no opportunity for the undergraduates to
get together except in mass-meetings held during lunch hours at
rather irregular intervals. There
was no time, it was said, when announcements of college activities
could be made and matters of general interest discussed.
Aiming to remedy this condition, the )dean and the faculty
went to considerable • trouble to
arrange the. schedule of classes in
such a way that one hour a week
could be left vacant so that massmeetings could be held regularly.
For a few weeks the plan worked
admirably. The hall in the Civil
Engineering Bulding was filled tp
capacity, and great enthusiasm
was displayed. Soon, however, it
became apparent that this enthusiasm was waning. At each meeting more and more seats were
vacant, while the barn became more
and more crowded. This condition
reached a climax last Thursday.
Dean Latane in addressing the
students stated in no uncertain
terms that unless more interest
was displayed the mass-meetings
would be.discontinued.
It can not be denied that these
meetings can and should be of
great value as a means of promoting college spirit and creating interest in the activities on the
campus. Are the students of this
university going to ignore the opportunity that is offered to them?

"LOVE NEST" SUNG BY ROBERTSON FEATURE OF
- COTILLION
Leading Man of "Mary" Introduced By
"Shorty" Stuart—Dance Great Success—Music By Bob Iula.

The second cotillion, held in the
Civil Engineering Building on Friday, March 18, was probably one
of the best parties ever held at
Homewood. The Cotillion Board
is to be congratulated on their
management, the changes they introduced to make the service more
efficient being very much appreciated. The event which made the
party the last word in success was
the presence of Mr.. Guy Robertson, who played the leading part
in "Mary" last week. Mr. Robertson very kindly consented to sing
the "Love Nest," and after being
introduced by "Shorty" Stuart he
gave this good old song with so
much richness of tone' and expression that he was repeatedly
encored.
The Ian was. very tastefully
decorated,' the .hangings and jonquils about the room carrying out
the suggestion of spring. The
front blackboard was especially
well done. It was divided diagonally into black and blue, with a
large yellow J. H. U. across- it.
The shield of the university was
then interposed between the verticals of the "II" in green and black,
which gave a most pleasing effect.
.Supper was served at 11.o'clock,
and the mad rush of previous cotillions was forgotten in the orderly
array of food to .which the stub
end.of the ticket admitted one in
the basement. No difficulty was
had by anyone in being served by
this method, and it is hoped that
this system will be continued during the next cotillons.
Music was furnished by Bob
Iula's orchestra, and they certainly
outdid themselves in the way they
gave the whole program. Bob
himself has become as .proficient
on the. saxophone as he is on the
flute and piccolo,, and he led the
orchestra with great skill. With
the help of streamers and confetti
the party became so "peppy" about
1 o'clock that when the lights began signalling for all out and the
music finally stopped at 1.30 everybody was feeling as if they could
keep on all night.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 22, 1921

OMICRON DELTA KAPPA TO
AWARD SERVICE CUP
To Be Given Every Year To Graduating Man Who Has Best Served
University—Faculty Committee To Pick Winner.

At the meeting of the Omicron
Delta Kappa Circle on Friday the
plan of awarding a service cup
was adopted in its final form as
follows:
The Johns Hopkins Circle of
soKappa
Delta
Omicron
ciety will award annually at the
Senior class day exercises a silver
loving cup to that member of the
graduating class who throughout
his college career has \most faithfully served the interests and
ideals of the university. This cup
is to be known as the Omicron
Delta Kappa service cup.
The award shall be judged by
the following committee:
Nonathletic Activities — Dr.
John C. French (chairman).
Athletics—Dr. Ray Van Orman.
College Spirit and Leadership—
Dr. John H. Latane (dean of arts
and science).
College Spirit and Leadership—
Dr. John B. Whitehead (dean of
engineering).
The dean of arts and sciences
shall grade only academic students
and the dean- of engineering shall
grade only engineering students.
Each dean shall select five members and each other judge ten
members of the graduating class
and• grade them on the basis of
their respective merits in the particular sphere of service which he
is to judge, as designated above,
ten for first, nine for second, etc.
Then the committees shall meet
and the Senior with the highest
aggregate score shall receive the
award. The judges shall have the
power to name one or more for
honorable mention and these
names are to be read at the tulle
of the presentation of the cup. In
case of a:tie the president of the
university shall cast the deciding
ballot.

THE ARCADE TEA ROOM

ANNUAL TENNIS TOURNAMENT TO BE HELD THIS
SPRING

As has been the custom in previous years, the regular spring
tennis tournament will be held
this year. The tournament will
begin as soon as the courts can
be gotten into shape.
Owing to the lax system of defaulting, last year's tournament
did not measure up to anticipations. However, a more efficient
system has been devised, and it is
hoped that with the co-operation
of the players this year's tournament can be run off more
smoothly. The entrance blanks,
which will be distributed in the
near future, contain a space for
the sehedule of classes and labopatories, and it is hoped in this way
to arrange matches at times most
convenient to the participants.
The drawings will be posted at
prominent places on the campus,
indicating the time of play for each
match. Failure to appear at the
time first set will not be considered a default, but a second absence will prevent the man from
further play: This is absolutely
necessary in order to conduct the
tournament successfully.
The entrance fee will be 50 cents,
and it is hoped that such a reasonable amount will enable a large
number of• entries to turn out.
The tournament will not have absolute bearing on the selection of
the team, but it will give an idea
about the available material.

LECTURES ON CHINA AND JAPAN
UNDER AUSPICES OF Y. M. C. A.

An opportunity for Hopkins
students to get acquainted with
two great Oriental countries is
to be offered by the Y. 3,I. C. A.
4luring the next two months.
American students are aware
)f the fact that China represents
me-fourth of the population of
:he entire world; that one of its
)rovinces, Shansi, has an un,ouched coal formation sufficient

to supply the entire world for
2,000 years,and that China is passing through one of the most critical stages of her history.
-Vague reports are heard of the
progressive development of Japan.
We know that in it, a country the
size- of the State of Montana, there
are 10,000 miles of railroads; that
the Government has contracted to
electrify the whole of it; that
from Yokohama to Tokyo express
trains run every ten minutes. .
However, there are many inter-

esting things relative to the political, social, economic, educational and religious aspects of
these great countries of which we
are but ill-informed,
Mr. Yao T'zu Li, of Tientsin,
China, a graduate of Tsing Hua
College, and Mr. Yasushi Ibara,
of Uwajaima, Japan, a graduate
of Randolph Macon College, a research student in the United
States Bureau of Fisheries will
lead classes on China and japan,
respectively. The classes will be

held, beginning this week, from
12.30 to 12.55 o'clock on Wednesdays in the M. E. auditorium.
Students interested are urged
to fill out and return the enrollment card which will be distributed, ,with a circular, through
the postoffice.

successful. About 80 couple were
present. The music furnished by
the undergraduates was excellent
and left nothing to be desired;
and the punch furnished by the
Junior Class was more than up to
expectations. In fact, the dance
was such an addition to the debate
and was so instrumental in bringing such a large crowd out that it
is probable that it will become a
customary event after all future
debates.

FRESHMAN BASEBALL
ORGANIZES.

TEAM

The Freshmen team held its first
practice last Thursday, at which
about 20 Freshman candidates
showed up. Altogether there are
about 30 Freshmen who have
turned in their names, and the
prospects of a very successful season are bright. "Doug" Turnbull,
who is coaching the team this
year, hopes to have a crackerjack
team in shape for the first game
with Mount St. Joseph's on Friday, April 1.
Manager Vanneman has arranged a very attractive schedule,
including two trips. A game is
pending with Episcopal High at
Alexandria on May 7 and efforts
are being made to play the Lehigh
Freshmen Team in Baltimore on
April 22.
The completed schedule to date
follows:
April 1—Mount St. Joseph's.
April 8—Poly.
April 15.—City College.
April 23—Tome (away).
April 29—Central High School
of Washington.
May 6—Army-Navy Prep.
May 13—McKinley High School
of Washington.
May 18—Friends School.
May 21—Central High School
of Washington (away).

"ARMS AND THE MAN"

FIRST JAZZ ,DEBATE A
DISTINCT SUCCESS.

Will Serve As Excellent Advertisement of University—New Men
Taken Into Club.

Seniors Fall Before Onslaught of Junior Speakers—"Mike" Bowers'
Orchestra Delights Dancers.
Large Attendance Attracted by Innovation

The Dramatic Club is now
deeply concerned with plans to
take "Arms and the Man" on the
road. It is hoped that later in
the spring it will be able to perform in some of the smaller Western Maryland towns. This will
offer an opportunity of introducing a Hopkins organization to
the people of that district and will
advertise the college besides enabling the club to get funds to
pay off some of the loans made by
members last year.
At the last meeting in the
studio the members of the cast
made eligible for membership in
the club by participation in "Arms
and the Man" were formally
taken in.
Although the performance of
"Arms and the Man" is over, every
one who saw it or took part in
it is still talking about it with
much praise. What speaks well
for the Dramatic Club is that little of the comment is obverse and
that critics in all places have commented most favorably on the production. Henry West, as Louka,
seems in most minds to have been
the best of the cast, the most
natural in his part and the best
costumed of the three female roles.
Joe Moran's voice was far less
like that of a heroine only because
of a very bad cold which he contracted several days before the
performance. Pierce Brawner is
still speaking of the jar he had
When in the second act he asked
Major Petkoff where Riana was,
only to have the girl herself
answer from behind "Riana is
here" in tones of very masculine
pitch, whereas Brawner had expected, a delicate soft response.
Mossom is coming in for his share
of praise along with Basford and
Trew for his excellent acting and
is being constantly reminded of
his idiosyncrasies in the part of
Major Petkoff which brought so
many laughs.
CROSS COUNTRY TEAM
At a meeting of the Athletic Association held March
17 it was recommended that
the Cross Country Team be
made an organization separate from the track team, and
that it elect its own special
captain. An "H" is to be
awarded any man placing in
the Southern Intercollegiate
Championships and a "cHc"
to a point winner in any other
meet. This recommendation
must be voted upon by the
student-body before it can
be adopted.

The Junior-Senior debate and
dance held last Saturday evening
was a distinct success. The debate—which the Juniors won by
unanimous decision — was well
contested, and the speakers held
the interest of the audience at all
times. The subject was: "Resolved, That the United States
should adopt a policy of further
material restriction of immigration." Morris Keen, first speaker
for the affirmative, argued that
the recent type of immigrant is
vastly inferior and less assimilable than the older type, and that
very few take the trouble to learn
our language. He claimed that
Europe needs its man-power now
if never before. Burdelle S. Cannon, first speaker for '21, said that
the present law, if properly enforced, is restrictive and strict
enough to efficiently exclude all
undesirables..
C. C. Marbury devoted his
speech to the dangers of Japanese
immigration, and showed that in
consideration of the very high
birth rate among the Japanese,
California will have come under
the control of the Japs by 1949,
unless some means is found to
stop the flood of Orientals. He
claimed that Japan is not living
up to the "Gentlemen's Agreement," and is sending laborers to
America in direct violation of this
agreement. He favored an immigration plan which would exclude
the Japanese and would limit
European immigrants• to 5 per
cent. of those already here; each
separate country to send immigrants in a definite proportion to
those who become nationalized in
this country. Harold Reed, for
the negative, denied that there are
any inherent objectionable faults
in the modern immigrant, and protested the statement that criminals
are usually aliens. He said that
we need the immigrant to do the
sort of "dirty work" that Americans refuse to do. Louis Macht
in the negative rebuttal drew a
laugh when he said:."My opponents have pointed out Owen Johnson as an authority favoring restriction of immtgration. Now,
Dr. Dunlap, sitting right here in
front of me, says that Owen Johnson appeals only to the lowest type
of intellect." Macht attempted to
refute. the- statement that there
will be more immigration in the
future than in the past. R. Dorsey
(Continued on page 8 col. 2)

BALL TEAM PREPARING FOR PETITION FOR LIMITATION
OF ENROLLMENT ENGAME WITH VIRGINIA
DORSED BY LEADING
MEN ON CAMPUS
Infield Positions Practically Filled.
Seven Men Showing Up Evenly
In Outfield—First Game At
Charlottesville On
March 26.

The Johns Hopkins basketball
team is rapidly rounding into excellent form for their first encounter with the University of Virginia
at Charlottesville, Va., on March
26. Coach Herb Armstrong has
a squad of 40 men working out
daily at Homewood and has been
having a difficult time picking out
the best combination but by elimidefinitely denation has almost'
cided upon the line-up for the
opening game.
Catchers who have been showing up well are "Bill" Wood, last
year's mainstay, and Levin. It is
quite likely that Wood will continue to receive the delivery of
Tucker, Shipley and Owings, Marchetti, Ellicott and Macht. Tucker
is a former St. John's man with
a good reputation and a strong
arm. Owings is through with basketball now and will endeavor to
get in form as rapidly as possible without injury to his arm.
Andy Knecht looks good at first
and with Grace at second, Reifschneider at short and Captain
Sharretts at third Hopkins has a
well balanced infield. Outfielders
are Mader, Merrick, Wells, Rich,
Chandler, Miller and Thomas; the
first three named bat left-handed
and all are sluggers. Thomas was
captain of last year's team at City
College and looks like the logical
man for one of the field positions.
Substitute infielders are Strouse
and Middleton, so that with this
formidable array of stars and exstars Hopkins' outlook for the
present season is quite favorable.
Freshmen practice was inaugurated Thursday, but only a few
men showed up. A schedule of
games has been arranged by Manager Vanneman, which includes
three trips away from home and
home games have been arranged
with some of the best prep teams
in this vicinity and with college
freshmen teams. Turnbull will
coach the Freshmen and with more
men out surely can develop a winning aggregation. Barton has
been catching for the first-year
men, with Chalmers on the mound
and McBurney at shortstop.
Mount, Pinder and Donnatell
have been holding down the outfield positions.

Members of Faculty Also hi Favor of
Plan To Go Before Committee
On Admission And Advanced
Standing Shortly.

Following the suggestion of
last week's NEWS-LETTER editorial
in reference to a limitation of
future freshmen enrollment, the
following petition has been drawn
up and been endorsed by several
members of the faculty, including
Drs. Ames, Roulston and French,
and by the leaders of practically
every athletic and nonathletic organization on the campus. Thehonorary fraternity, Omicron
Delta Kappa, is also heartily in
favor of the move, which will
place the limited facilities of the
university in the hands of those
most deserving them. The petition
will be placed for ratification before the Committee on Admissions
and Advanced Standing at the
next meeting of that body.
The petition follows:
Whereas, the university is unable because of inadequate facilities to provide suitable education
for a larger number of students
than are now enrolled.
Whereas, the great increase in
the number of students without
the proper facilities for taking
care of them has impaired the
standing, college
educational
spirit and environment of other
colleges and universities.
Whereas, we fear that there is
danger of a similar condition of
affairs at our own university, we
submit the following petition:
That the size of the class of
1925 and succeeding classes be
limited to a fixed number.
That the admission of students
to the university in the future be
based not solely upon scholarship
but upon character and personality as well.
And that in all cases where possible a personal interview with the
dean or.Committee on Admissions
and Advanced Standing be required.

TRACK MEN
K. R. Mulliken, captain of
the Johns. Hopkins Track
Team, is desirous that all
former track men and any
.candidates who. wish to try
for places on the team report
to the Homewood field daily
at 3.45 P. M. for practice.
An attractive schedule of
meets has been arranged for
the outdoor season, which
promises to be every bit as
successful as was the indoor
season.

MODEST ACTOR DIAGNOSES HOPKINS' ILLS.

Last Thursday, in the neighborhood of 2 o'clock, the university
was honored by an unofficial visit
from Guy Robertson, leading man
with "Mary," the musical comedy
playing in town last week.
Modestly clad in a dove-colored
soft hat, cream-colored overcoat,
checker-board vest and a flowing
green tie, the blue-eyed dispenser
of love and music "jazzed" into the
Student Activities Building and
proceeded to make himself at
home.
After "kidding" everyone in the
athletic office, he sobered down
long enough to tell about himself.
After spending three years at
Lehigh, studying "at" civil engineering, playing quarterback on
the football team, having his nose
broken in the annual Lafayette
clash and finally "flunking," he
left by "mutual consent," returned
home to little old New York and
entered vaudeville. From then he
rose, till at his present age of 21,
he ascended to the heights of musical comedy in "Mary.
He diagnosed Hopkins' troubles
in few words. Too many students;
too few athletes, too much blacklist and too few co-eds is the
trouble mostly. And he finished
by saying we'd never beat Lehigh
in lacrosse again.
After which he offered to treat
everyone present, bought a fountain ipen from Dr. Adams,
pocketed the $495 change (of his
week's salary) and went "jazzing"
back to Ford's to sing "Love
Nest" softly to Virginia O'Brien.

MUSICAL CLUB GIVES
CONCERT
Hopkins Musicians Delight Audience
At Harlem Square Church.
Speaker Loses Suspender Button.

The concert given by the combined musical clubs at the Harlem
Square Church last Wednesday
night, March 16, which was in
reality more or less of a dress
rehearsal, was very successful.
The program was opened by the
singing of the Univ_ersity Ode by
the Glee Club. The Orchestra
rallied nobly to an Intermezzo
from Iris, "Mike" Bowers directing with a black fountain pen.
Coulter, accompanied by the Glee
Club, next sang "On the Road to
Maudalay," which was received in
grand style. The audience now
being thoroughly asleep was suddenly aroused by the Orchestra
playing a martial air in staccato
time. The Quartet retaliated with
"The Cornfield Melody," composed
by Mr. Speaker, director of the
club. Following up with an encore, Mr. Speaker and Coulter
sang "Johnnie Schmoker," during
which Mr. Speaker, in leaning
over, lost his suspender button,
much to the merriment of the
audience. The Hawaiian Trio was
excellent, performing in old-time
Hambleton played the
style.
"Rosary" on the steel guitar and
Coulter rendered the "Melody in
F" on the ukelele. The concert
was brought to a successful close
by the playing of "Look for the
Silver Lining," medley from
"Sally," by the Mandolin Club,
and "De Coppah Moon" by the
Glee Club.

C. I. T. Gould, representing
Johns Hopkins, won second place
in the Intercollegiate Southern
Oratorical League Contest held at
Chapel Hill, N. C., last week.
Gould's subject was "America and
the Japanese." David Reid Hodgin, of North Carolina, whose subject was "War Declared," won
first place, while Patrick Henry
Vincent, University of Kentucky,
who spoke on the "Anglo-Irish
Controversy," was third. C. D.
Pepper, of Alabama, presented the
"Immigration Problem"; George
R. Jacob, of Virginia, spoke on the
"Truth About• America," and
Walter T. Whitewell, of Vanderbilt University, had as a subject
"Wanted—A School of Diplomacy." Georgia University and
the University of Tennessee were
entered in the contest but failed
to send representatives.
In attacking his subject Gould
did not favor exclusion of the
Japanese on grounds of inferiority
but for the cause of world peace
and because of racial difference
and the economic well-being of the
American people. He advocated
the abolition of the existing "gentlemen's agreement" and urged a
policy of exclusion in its place.
The presiding officer of the contest was Mr. W.H. Close, of North
Carolina, and the judges were W.
F. Boatwright, president of University of Richmond; Prof. C. R.
Brown, of Roanoke College, and
Prof. Yates Snowden, of the University of South Carolina.
After the contest there was a
banquet at which the constitution
of the league was amended and
it was decided that hereafter instead of the money prizes of $30,
$20 and $10 to winners of first,
second and third places, cups of
medals of corresponding value
would be offered. The contest for
next year was awarded to the
University of Alabama. Officers
of the league were elected as follows: President, C. I. T. Gould,
Johns Hopkins; chairman, Professor McKee, University of North
Carolina; secretary, Mr. McCall,
of Alabama.

UNIT SUFFERING FROM
ABSENTEES
Number of Delinquents Only Cause For
Concern After Two Official Inspections of R. 0. T. C. Last
Week—Many Opportunities In Regular Army
For Seniors.

The one thing that is holding
back the Johns Hopkins Unit of
the R. 0. T. C. in its attempts to
become proficient enough to receive the first place on the "distinguished" list this spring is the
number of inexcused absences
from • drill and classes that are
not made up. This, according to
Major Gary, is the one pronounced
weakness of the unit at present.
The two important inspections of
the military department that occurred last week emphasized the
many blanks on the attendance
charts hanging in the military
office. The first of these inspections was by the office of the
chief of infantry, which has jurisdiction. over Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia. In general
both sets of inspectors appeared
to be very much impressed with
the work being done at Hopkins,
and one officer, after making his
examination and seeing how the
various theoretical classes were
conducted, stated that he thought
that the work being done here was
of as high order as that of any
unit in the country, and further
that he thought that Hopkins
should be made the model unit for
the United States. If the unexcused absences, ranging all
through the year, are made up
and students continue to show
their present interest in the work
and keep up its high quality,
Major Gary believes the rating of
the institution will be very high.
Certainly with a few exceptions
the members of the unit, both officers and students, are bending
every effort to secure the highest
possible rating at the "distinguished" inspection in the spring.
The War Department is giving
to seniors in selected institutions
(among which is Hopkins) exceptional opportunities to enter
the regular army as commissioned
officers, and particularly does this
apply to engineering students.
There are at present vacancies in
the Ordnance Department, in the
Signal Corps and in the Corps of
Engineers. Major Gary believes
that students entering the army
on graduation this spring will be
first lieutenants within a few
months. As such they would receive as pay and allowances a
salary of about $3,000 a year.
Exemptions from examinations
before appointment to a commission will be given to those who
have a certain class standing at
the university. It is Major
Gary's opinion that this condition, where commissions may be
so easily secured and to such good
advantage, will not exist again for
years. Those who are interested
in entering the army should apply
to the military office for further
information.

The following method, with

All nominations are written and

Although such a system of elections is more complicated than the
one now in use, it has obvious advantages and, having been used
successfully in many other colleges is certainly worthy of the
consideration of our student council.

STUDENT

Spring, the time - for baseball,
love, cutting classes and elections,
is again with us if the weather,
the robins and our internal feelings are true indications. "Shad"
and Armstrong will take care of
baseball, Baltimore will supply
the girl and the dean will attend
to those delinquents who find the
study of nature more interesting
than the prescribed courses. Elections apparently take care of
themselves.
We have long thought that the
system of class and other student
elections used at Hopkins in the
past is far from satisfactory. The
election of class and student officials should be a matter of careful and weighty consideration. The
men elected represent the students
by whom they are elected, and
upon them will depend largely the
initiative and spirit of those they
represent.

For a good many years Hopkins
students have been criticised for
their lack of college spirit. The
reply to this criticism' has always
been that there was no opportunity for the undergraduates to
get together except in mass-meetings held during lunch hours at
rather irregular intervals. There
was no time, it was said, when announcements of college activities
could be made and matters of general interest discussed.
Aiming to remedy this condition, the )dean and the faculty
went to considerable • trouble to
arrange the. schedule of classes in
such a way that one hour a week
could be left vacant so that massmeetings could be held regularly.
For a few weeks the plan worked
admirably. The hall in the Civil
Engineering Bulding was filled tp
capacity, and great enthusiasm
was displayed. Soon, however, it
became apparent that this enthusiasm was waning. At each meeting more and more seats were
vacant, while the barn became more
and more crowded. This condition
reached a climax last Thursday.
Dean Latane in addressing the
students stated in no uncertain
terms that unless more interest
was displayed the mass-meetings
would be.discontinued.
It can not be denied that these
meetings can and should be of
great value as a means of promoting college spirit and creating interest in the activities on the
campus. Are the students of this
university going to ignore the opportunity that is offered to them?

"LOVE NEST" SUNG BY ROBERTSON FEATURE OF
- COTILLION
Leading Man of "Mary" Introduced By
"Shorty" Stuart—Dance Great Success—Music By Bob Iula.

The second cotillion, held in the
Civil Engineering Building on Friday, March 18, was probably one
of the best parties ever held at
Homewood. The Cotillion Board
is to be congratulated on their
management, the changes they introduced to make the service more
efficient being very much appreciated. The event which made the
party the last word in success was
the presence of Mr.. Guy Robertson, who played the leading part
in "Mary" last week. Mr. Robertson very kindly consented to sing
the "Love Nest," and after being
introduced by "Shorty" Stuart he
gave this good old song with so
much richness of tone' and expression that he was repeatedly
encored.
The Ian was. very tastefully
decorated,' the .hangings and jonquils about the room carrying out
the suggestion of spring. The
front blackboard was especially
well done. It was divided diagonally into black and blue, with a
large yellow J. H. U. across- it.
The shield of the university was
then interposed between the verticals of the "II" in green and black,
which gave a most pleasing effect.
.Supper was served at 11.o'clock,
and the mad rush of previous cotillions was forgotten in the orderly
array of food to .which the stub
end.of the ticket admitted one in
the basement. No difficulty was
had by anyone in being served by
this method, and it is hoped that
this system will be continued during the next cotillons.
Music was furnished by Bob
Iula's orchestra, and they certainly
outdid themselves in the way they
gave the whole program. Bob
himself has become as .proficient
on the. saxophone as he is on the
flute and piccolo,, and he led the
orchestra with great skill. With
the help of streamers and confetti
the party became so "peppy" about
1 o'clock that when the lights began signalling for all out and the
music finally stopped at 1.30 everybody was feeling as if they could
keep on all night.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 22, 1921

OMICRON DELTA KAPPA TO
AWARD SERVICE CUP
To Be Given Every Year To Graduating Man Who Has Best Served
University—Faculty Committee To Pick Winner.

At the meeting of the Omicron
Delta Kappa Circle on Friday the
plan of awarding a service cup
was adopted in its final form as
follows:
The Johns Hopkins Circle of
soKappa
Delta
Omicron
ciety will award annually at the
Senior class day exercises a silver
loving cup to that member of the
graduating class who throughout
his college career has \most faithfully served the interests and
ideals of the university. This cup
is to be known as the Omicron
Delta Kappa service cup.
The award shall be judged by
the following committee:
Nonathletic Activities — Dr.
John C. French (chairman).
Athletics—Dr. Ray Van Orman.
College Spirit and Leadership—
Dr. John H. Latane (dean of arts
and science).
College Spirit and Leadership—
Dr. John B. Whitehead (dean of
engineering).
The dean of arts and sciences
shall grade only academic students
and the dean- of engineering shall
grade only engineering students.
Each dean shall select five members and each other judge ten
members of the graduating class
and• grade them on the basis of
their respective merits in the particular sphere of service which he
is to judge, as designated above,
ten for first, nine for second, etc.
Then the committees shall meet
and the Senior with the highest
aggregate score shall receive the
award. The judges shall have the
power to name one or more for
honorable mention and these
names are to be read at the tulle
of the presentation of the cup. In
case of a:tie the president of the
university shall cast the deciding
ballot.

THE ARCADE TEA ROOM

ANNUAL TENNIS TOURNAMENT TO BE HELD THIS
SPRING

As has been the custom in previous years, the regular spring
tennis tournament will be held
this year. The tournament will
begin as soon as the courts can
be gotten into shape.
Owing to the lax system of defaulting, last year's tournament
did not measure up to anticipations. However, a more efficient
system has been devised, and it is
hoped that with the co-operation
of the players this year's tournament can be run off more
smoothly. The entrance blanks,
which will be distributed in the
near future, contain a space for
the sehedule of classes and labopatories, and it is hoped in this way
to arrange matches at times most
convenient to the participants.
The drawings will be posted at
prominent places on the campus,
indicating the time of play for each
match. Failure to appear at the
time first set will not be considered a default, but a second absence will prevent the man from
further play: This is absolutely
necessary in order to conduct the
tournament successfully.
The entrance fee will be 50 cents,
and it is hoped that such a reasonable amount will enable a large
number of• entries to turn out.
The tournament will not have absolute bearing on the selection of
the team, but it will give an idea
about the available material.

LECTURES ON CHINA AND JAPAN
UNDER AUSPICES OF Y. M. C. A.

An opportunity for Hopkins
students to get acquainted with
two great Oriental countries is
to be offered by the Y. 3,I. C. A.
4luring the next two months.
American students are aware
)f the fact that China represents
me-fourth of the population of
:he entire world; that one of its
)rovinces, Shansi, has an un,ouched coal formation sufficient

to supply the entire world for
2,000 years,and that China is passing through one of the most critical stages of her history.
-Vague reports are heard of the
progressive development of Japan.
We know that in it, a country the
size- of the State of Montana, there
are 10,000 miles of railroads; that
the Government has contracted to
electrify the whole of it; that
from Yokohama to Tokyo express
trains run every ten minutes. .
However, there are many inter-

esting things relative to the political, social, economic, educational and religious aspects of
these great countries of which we
are but ill-informed,
Mr. Yao T'zu Li, of Tientsin,
China, a graduate of Tsing Hua
College, and Mr. Yasushi Ibara,
of Uwajaima, Japan, a graduate
of Randolph Macon College, a research student in the United
States Bureau of Fisheries will
lead classes on China and japan,
respectively. The classes will be

held, beginning this week, from
12.30 to 12.55 o'clock on Wednesdays in the M. E. auditorium.
Students interested are urged
to fill out and return the enrollment card which will be distributed, ,with a circular, through
the postoffice.

The Hawaiian Trio failed to

The informal dance that followed the debate was exceedingly
successful. About 80 couple were
present. The music furnished by
the undergraduates was excellent
and left nothing to be desired;
and the punch furnished by the
Junior Class was more than up to
expectations. In fact, the dance
was such an addition to the debate
and was so instrumental in bringing such a large crowd out that it
is probable that it will become a
customary event after all future
debates.

FRESHMAN BASEBALL

TEAM

The Freshmen team held its first
practice last Thursday, at which
about 20 Freshman candidates
showed up. Altogether there are
about 30 Freshmen who have
turned in their names, and the
prospects of a very successful season are bright. "Doug" Turnbull,
who is coaching the team this
year, hopes to have a crackerjack
team in shape for the first game
with Mount St. Joseph's on Friday, April 1.
Manager Vanneman has arranged a very attractive schedule,
including two trips. A game is
pending with Episcopal High at
Alexandria on May 7 and efforts
are being made to play the Lehigh
Freshmen Team in Baltimore on
April 22.
The completed schedule to date
follows:
April 1—Mount St. Joseph's.
April 8—Poly.
April 15.—City College.
April 23—Tome (away).
April 29—Central High School
of Washington.
May 6—Army-Navy Prep.
May 13—McKinley High School
of Washington.
May 18—Friends School.
May 21—Central High School
of Washington (away).
